author: th4s_
content: Does anyone have some good resources on how the networking behind e.g. geth works? How does it find its peers? Which protocols are involved (udp/tcp)? What periodic data exchanges happen between nodes? Are peers shuffled, after some time? And so on...?

author: peter.davies
content: https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p is the standard used I believe.

author: 0xcthae
content:
Hello there!
I am Mehul. I am a software developer mainly working with C++/python. I recently started getting involved with blockchain development and I am learning rust and solidity for the purpose, but I find myself more attracted to the underlying protocol. I applied for the apprenticeship to learn more about EVM and ease into the process of contributing as a core developer.
I just went through most of the messages in the channel and will get back to all of you once I go through the github page for the cohort and all the prerequisites.
Glad to be here

author: lammatail223169
content: Hey Everyone, I'm Andrew and just applied today. Wish I had known about this channel sooner. My background is mostly analytics with a CS degree. I've done a good bit of static/dynamic analysis work academically. I'm interesting in how we can infer run time behavior of the EVM from OP code definition choices. (like an unexpected DOS vector????!) let me know your thoughts!

author: lammatail223169
content: Also this is a game I like to play; True/False "The EVM is fully defined in the yellow paper?"

author: lammatail223169
content: True/False the amount of  memory at runtime available to the EVM depends on the hardware/client (amount not type)

author: lammatail223169
content: My understanding is the working memory is an 8 bit array of infinite size. Would love to discuss if that is not correct

author: lammatail223169
content: True or False: You can process information in memory at run time that will never end up stored on the blockchain

author: pipermerriam
content: This seems like a DOS vector if it's truly infinite.....

author: lammatail223169
content: oh I suppose gas limits = your memory limits

author: lammatail223169
content: I wonder what a block designed to maximize use of local memory would do. I'm sure the client teams must have thought of that at some point ðŸ¤”

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Yep, the worst case for that would be something like this
```
jumpdest
gas
gas
mstore
push1 0x00
jump
```
which would continuously fill up the ram.
One iteration of the loop costs 1+2+2+3+3+8 = 17 gas
Given our limit of 30.000.000 gas (after 1559) this would result in 30.000.000/17*32/1024/1024 = 53MB memory usage per gas

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: So not a problem ðŸ˜‰

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: You can create even worse blocks though, but I leave that as a challenge ðŸ™‚
